results.content: This course is a couple years old, so maybe that's why I hada few concerns. I'm not exactly a newbie when it comes to Web development, but I am when it comes to design. This is definately the prettiest website I've ever built! But...it's so pixel-perfect and precise. That's my only complaint - when I've built websites in the past I've relied heavily on percentages and ems and almost never on pixels. I'm just not exactly sure it's a "Best practice" course. However, it's still a great course and it doesn't take very long to learn a lot and get a lot of worthwhile tips!

results.content:
One of the main thins people will struggle with when teaching themselves through videos on the internet is really nailing down the workflow of people already in the job they are training themselves for. While some may be fortunate enough to be able to ask people already in the know, most other are not. This is, to me, the primary reason this course was an incredible help to me.

Brad shows you how to structure your HTML and CSS files by looking at a PSD mock-up he has created, breaks it down the exact same way as people who do this for a living do (I know, I asked some!) and shows you how to go from nothing to a full web-page.

If you are new to HTML and CSS, I would very strongly advise you start with his other course for HTML & CSS beginners. I know enough to do this course comfortably but there were still some new things for me to learn in that regard, so I can imagine this being quite daunting if you know no HTML and CSS, plus you won't learn as much.

Giving this 4/5 and not 5/5 because some of the lectures clip at the end and some of the videos make it very hard to read what is being typed. Otherwise this would have got 5/5!

Thanks for this course Brad, and I look forward to buying more from you, such as the Bootstrap 3 course!

I recently took a Responsive Web Design course on Udemy with a much more streamlined way of coding for multiple screens and a LOT less CSS. results.content:
I'm a seasoned developer keeping my skills current. I have little design background and was hoping for more design for web type action in the course. However, for me, I didn't get much out of the course except a refresher on some HTML5/CSS3 (which isn't a bad thing). If you are a designer and new to web technology, then this is a good course to get started. I personally wanted more Photoshop time.

Brad was a bit lighter on editing this course. He uses several...uuummm...filler words and several mistakes were not edited out. Also, most of the time, the code font was a bit too small to follow along on my PC and was unwatchable on my iPad.

The last lecture felt too much like a commercial for a hosting company Brad is promoting (affiliate marketing). I do appreciate Brad disclosing that fact during the video, but I still think affiliate marketing is better suited for free courses.

results.content:
I've been designing websites since 1997 and professionally since 2002. I usually lag a little behind the curve. I like to see what technology catches on and get a good glimpse at the future before committing to anything new. My biggest hangup with HTML5 and CSS3 was limited browser support. 

When I decided to take this course it was just to bring me up to speed on the new features of HTML5 and CSS3 and get me headed in the right direction. 

Not only did this course do that for me but I quickly realized this course is great for any skill level. Beginner, Intermediate and Professionals alike!

Very easy to follow, very educational and I had a blast taking the course.

The only real issues with the course are the video quality isn't that great and the audio needs normalized for a bit more volume. Despite these two short comings I HIGHLY recommend this course!

results.content:
I do not recommend this class, as I had trouble following along, even though I work with Photoshop semi-regularly and knew HTML & CSS going in.

The instructor, Mr. Hussey, jumped around often, changing from explaining beforehand, in-the-middle-of, and directly after. Consistency on that approach would have been nice. There were also several instances of him utilizing code - but not explaining it whatsoever. In addition, Mr. Hussey seemed to have recorded everything in one take, making mistakes more than once, losing his train of thought, and repeating himself throughout the course.

The "tests" may as well have not existed at all, as they were all simple true/false or multiple choice questions with basic information you either already knew, or had no idea of what they were (which this class would not help you answer).

I did pick up on the existence of some elements and a few tips as far as organizing code.

Mr. Hussey's class seemed amateurish at best, due to issues I mentioned and the lack of explanations (and glut of over-explanations) at times. With some editing and more consistency, this class would have been much better.

results.content:
I used to code websites, but haven't touched markup/css in a few years, so this course was a nice quick and short refresher. I was only curious about the authors workflow, how it differs from mine and does he have any tricks i haven't seen before. 

It turns out i am not as rusty as i thought, this course was just enough for everything to come back to me.  I didn't forget to code, just haven't had the need to write it. 

Great usage of some of the advanced CSS3 selectors, i will definitely pick up some CSS3 and HTML5 books to get up to speed.  Also, i took upon myself to design in Photoshop, and code a few more websites, as an extra exercise.

The videos were great, good audio and video quality, clear, concise explanations and easy to follow instructions. I have a big 24" monitor so i had no trouble seeing all the code that was being written, as some people reported.

There's no substitute for coding everything yourself, as opposed to simply copying and pasting code.  so roll up your sleeves and write that code by hand, and you will get the most out of this course. 

Regads,
D.

results.content:
I understand this was created in 2012, but in 2019 it leaves you without any real-world skills. The lesson will not show you at all how to use Photoshop to create a mock-up. That is already done for you. You instead, get to slice up somebody else's mock-up, and begin writing HTML. Its primary focus is HTML and CSS, which he actually uses his finished HTML file as a reference to each and every change. 

I came into this course with those skills in hand, so I was not impressed. I thought it was a a poor strategy that he introduces some more advanced topics of CSS like transitions, but then encourages you to simply type them in and research on your own  how they work. I get it, trial and error leads to success, but when you pay for a course, you should be instructed the material, especially if you are using it in the lesson. I would have preferred you not even include advanced topics if you are not going to explain them in any detail.

I have used Photoshop enough to know that there are easier ways to achieve this lesson, but I figured I would be learning those. 

The part that made me least happy was when the finished product was crafted and I found it was completely non-responsive. The page is only designed to look good on a ~900px to ~1600px wide screen.

I hate to be so hard on this course, but I was thoroughly unimpressed and disappointed.

results.content:
Este curso, aun permitiendo mejorar tu conocimiento sobre HTML5/CSS3 tiene varios problemas de base, desde mi perspectiva personal:
* Siendo un curso etiquetado como Essentials, se dice en varias ocasiones que conocimiento previo de HTML y CSS viene bien... Bueno, si requiere conocimiento previo no puedes etiquetarlo como un "essentials".
* El curso "requiere" conocimiento y uso de Photoshop para seguirlo cómodamente. Esto para mi es un error de base.
Puesto que para crear webs en HTML5 y CSS no es necesario saber Photoshop, que dicho conocimiento sea requerido para "seguir" un curso es un requisito que debería haberse evitado.
* Aunque el Nombre del curso es HTML5/CSS3 Essentials, dentro del curso las lecciones lo nombran como PSD to HTML5/CSS3 que es un contenido bastante distinto.
* Cada vez que se trata un punto de CSS3 el autor recurre a las frases: "We're gonna get into some CSS3 fun",
"I'm not gonna dive into this, how this works",
"follow along and just copy it", 
"You don't necessarily need to know why it works",
"if you are interested you can do a little research on CSS3". Evidentemente esto no es lo que busco en un curso de CSS3. Vale que es Essentials, pero si usas algo como mínimo explica como funciona y refiere exactamente donde ver más detalle. Nunca son aceptables las sentencias del tipo copia esto y listo... Para eso uso google y copio de otros sites. Pero esto es un curso y debe enseñar.

* El curso adolece de otra serie de deficiencias menores relacionadas con el no ser un curso realizado por expertos como diferencias de nivel de audio entre lecciones lo que te obligará a ajustar el volumen a cada paso, la falta de edición posterior a la grabación hace que tengamos que perder el tiempo mientras el profesor busca una nota en sus papeles (incluso le puedes oir pasando páginas), el profesor tiene un tik nervioso de golpear con los dedos en la mesa que también llega al alumno... Como digo son cosas menores, pero contribuye a seguir restando puntos.

En definitiva el curso es aprovechable, pero ni tiene la mejor estructura, ni está ordenado de la mejor manera, ni se enfoca adecuadamente en los que yo considero que son puntos más importantes, ni emplea el tiempo de la mejor manera posible (una lección sobre como recortar en photoshop me parece un despropósito).
Para terminar en un tono positivo diré que el profesor es claro en sus explicaciones y tiene una voz placentera que permite mantener la atención con facilidad.

results.content: Anyone who has scoured the web in search for HTML5 tutorials (like myself) should definitely consider this (Brad's) course. I'm not new to web design, but the pace and difficulty I think was "just right" even for a true beginner. The reason(s) I knocked off 1 star was because of a couple annoyances: 1) it was hard to read the text as he typed in his editor (wish he had zoomed to his cursor more often), 2) he used some advanced CSS3 selectors/pseudo-selectors without much explanation towards the end (wish he had given us a slightly better explanation on why they were being used, rather than telling us to research them ourselves). But overall, great class!

The reason(s) I knocked off 1 star was because of a couple annoyances: 1) it was hard to read the text as he typed in his editor (wish he had zoomed to his cursor more often), 2) he used some advanced CSS3 selectors/pseudo-selectors without much explanation towards the end (wish he had given us a slightly better explanation on why they were being used, rather than telling us to research them ourselves). But overall, great class!

results.content:
This class started very well. Brad did a great job of patiently going through the PSD template in Photoshop, showing step by step method to extract images/resources for making the website. Even he helped us learning many useful keyboard shortcuts. 

But as soon as he moved to CSS coding section, he switched from 'Instructor' mode to 'advanced coder'. He typed so quickly, not waiting for the learner to type it in, switching back and forth between the browser and editor to see the effect. I had a hard time following up and had to pause the video number of times to really follow what he was doing. 

I prefer not to blindly type what the instructor types, but learn a bit so that if I am creating a website on my own, I am not completely lost. But, the instructor continued to be faster and faster with the coding that it was almost hard to follow. 

My suggestion to the instructor is to see from the perspective of a learner. (even better, take a completely new programming course on Udemy to understand the learner mode). A best instructor knows when to pause for the participants at the right time. 

The class was well organized and had a good flow. I wish it was little slower, so that I would not lag behind and lost the interest. 

Thanks. I hope this is useful for the participants as well as instructor.

results.content:
This course does exactly what it says in the title. You will code a website in 4 hours. That is, however, very different from saying you will LEARN TO code a website in 4 hours.

Far too many lines and concepts go unexplained, and I got increasingly annoyed with the constant "I will not dive into this" comments from the instructor when forced to add a piece of "CSS trickery" he did not seem to want to introduce. That gives me the impression the course was not carefully planned in advance, and he was just improvising as he went along with no clear progression - a feeling I had throughout the entire course. 

Even more confusingly, the instructor often spends time explaining the very basic and blatantly obvious, only to later skip clarifying the slightly more complex, in an apparent contradiction to the course’s stated minimum required skills. If a concept being utilised (such as “clearfix") plays such a central role in the design, I would expect it to have its use at least defined.

Mostly, it just felt like long sessions of switching between the video and my code editor to mechanically copy the code that was being written, with little to no explanation or clarification of why, as well as being directed to third-party web resources to read "if you wish to know more”. 

Don't get me wrong, I did extract some good learning from this course, and there is value in following along. However, learning any language - not just computer language - requires more than just writing words without knowing their meaning or reasons behind it, lest the learning runs the risk of becoming a fixed mental model that is not adaptable or replicable. I expect an instructor to guide me progressively through the topics, so later I will feel competent enough to replicate my learning on my own. I am sorry to say, I don’t in this case.

The course is thus not recommended for beginners, and those with a little experience might feel slightly bored. Well presented, however, some good tips and good voice and production, and inspires you to seek to learn more. It is good practice if you wish to refresh your basic HTML and CSS skills, but if you really want to learn to code, there are better options out there.

results.content:
What attracted me to the title of the course was the idea of incorporating Photoshop with HTML5/CSS3, and while technically that happens in the course, it wasn't entirely what I expected. Having said that, the course provides some solid bits of information regarding how to take a Photoshop mockup and recreate it as a semantically-valid HTML5/CSS3 web page. I didn't have trouble following along, but I believe that's due to my familiarity with basic HTML and CSS concepts. An absolute beginner is likely to get lost in the weeds pretty quickly. In fairness, the instructor does say that some background would be helpful; in my view, it's essential.

My main criticism is the quality of the video itself. When you are writing code, you have to be able to read the code. It wasn't until halfway through the course that the video zoomed into the code itself so that it could be read. Otherwise, you'll find yourself pausing and rewinding unless you are a fast and accurate keyboarder (which I am not). Somewhat frustrating.

The instructor might have been a bit more organized in his presentation, but it wasn't a big problem.

Overall, I learned some things from this course, and would recommend it to those who already have some HTML/CSS knowledge and who want to take a Photoshop mockup from concept to final coding.

Given 3 stars simply because i've done a large portion of the Ruby for Enterpenears and found that one better and gave 4 stars (so couldn't give this the same rating). 
Author goes through material slowly although for me, a bit too slowly. In some places things were not explained so I was somewhat unsure of the targeted audience(i.e in some places it's geared towards novices rather than beginners and yet the videos go so slowly it seems targeted at beginners. It seems to want some previous knowledge in CSS but then will explain basics of CSS so the hour I spent before hand going through CSS was a bit pointless lol). A lot of material could be condensed or removed, no need for the introductions each time at the beginning of tutorials for example, I know what course i'm taking and the title because I clicked on it lol. Additionally, having to wake a few seconds a few times a video for you to find information is annoying and gives the impression the series has been poorly planned. Please pause videos and do this if you need too; for those of us with poor concentration/attention, that's a way to loose it very quickly! Not trying to come across harsh, but just give constructive feedback. I've watched a lot of online videos! :)

Overall though, really good and helpful tutorial series. It's something every web developer will need to know and having a series which gives a bigger picture of the process involved is really good! Recommended and look forward to seeing what else the instructor creates in the future.

results.content:
Overall, this is a PHENOMENAL course. Brad does a great job of teaching how to take apart a PSD and take those same elements and convert it to a web page using HTML and CSS. I took it after completing the HTML/CSS portion of his Complete Web Design course and it really helped to re-inforce that portion of the course.

However, it might be a bit overwhelming if you don't have any prior experience with Photoshop or with HTML/CSS, so you may have to watch some of the videos more than once. (But with some practice, you should be able to easily duplicate what you're seeing in the videos.)

The only thing I didn't like is there were a few times Brad would be in the middle of a lecture and would add a CSS element that he hadn't introduced, and would say "I'm not going to explain this in detail; if you want to know more check out such-and-such website." Mind you, probably 98% of the material was properly introduced and explained, but I feel like if you use something in your lectures, you should be willing to explain to your students what it is and how it works.

That said, I've taken about a dozen courses in web design on udemy, and Brad Hussey is one of the better instructors - and this course is definitely worth checking out.

results.content:
Brad's done a very nice job of putting together this course. I found the pop quizzes to be good follow up to the points in the lessons. I knew based on my quiz results whether I needed to revisit some of the topics for better understanding. I am now moving on to his Bootstrap 3 course, which I'm definitely looking forward to. 

Only minor complaint (which, sadly, I find in many courses) is the use of a mic that picks up far too much of the ambient sounds in the room. Since many of us use ear buds to listen to the course, it can be a bit annoying to hear every keyboard tap / mouse click / fan hum, etc. because an omnidirectional mic was used rather than a directional aimed mainly at picking up the teacher's narration.

Fortunately Brad has a good speaking voice and style so, by comparison to another course I recently signed up for (and I won't be mean and mention here), it wasn't too distracting. The other course I couldn't even finish because the teacher wasn't organized to begin with and then constantly had lip smacks, chair squeaks, and other noises overshadowing the narration. I finally gave up on that one.

I made it through the PSD to HTML5/CSS3 course in one evening and have reviewed a few of the videos for refreshers since.

Excellent course!

results.content:
Brad did a great job of breaking down the basics of what it really takes to put together a very professional website from a PSD file in a highly effective and efficient manner.  Having the code to refer to in separate files helped a lot, as did having extra documents that outlined additional resources.

Things that might bug you:  The first video tutorial dealing with the extraction of web elements is as much as lesson in how to use Photoshop as anything else, and didn't much cover *why* you want to pick out certain elements over others.  Also, there was a high level of assumption about the viewer's environment.  If you're brand new and have never coded anything or worked with graphics programs at all, this might be a little steep.

The video quality is pretty bad, you can't really tell what Brad is typing while he's doing it.  The comments supported my experience, but, again, having the finished code in other documents made up for it (though it was a little annoying to have to pause the video, find the snippet, realize "Oh, hey, I guess 'florp' isn't a word after all', and then get on it with the lesson).  The audio is not consistent from video to video so be prepared to have to adjust the volume at the beginning of each one.

However, in the end, I still give it Five Stars because it accomplished its goal beautifully and delivered above and beyond.  The extra couple of videos at the end were wonderful, especially the Sticky Footer video.  I highly recommend this.

results.content:
This course is an excellent and engaging introduction to HTML and CSS.

The instructor is clearly knowledgeable in what he teaches. And Brad conveys his knowledge in a series of refreshingly short yet effective lectures. The emphasis is on actually coding a sample web page, and one which appropriately requires covering many commonly encountered facets of HTML and CSS such as cursor hovering effects and floats. He also utilizes good coding practices for organizing and commenting code. I enjoyed his course so much, I'm now moving on to his Bootstrap and WordPress course.

I have only one minor criticism. I'd personally have liked more explanation of the topic of clearfix within this course. Though the instructor at least provides a link to an external information page for further reading, one would expect common issues for HTML and CSS coders to be adequately addressed within the scope of the course itself.

But Brad otherwise covers the basics quite well, well enough to give me the confidence to produce a basic but effective and very decently styled web page on my own.

I noticed a few course reviewers pointed out the course is now over four years old as of the date of this review (Jan 2017). Though I'm obviously no expert, I believe this course is still very valid at this time. Not much appears to have changed or been added to either HTML or CSS since 2012. HTML 5 is still the standard, and while a few CSS 4 modules have been released since 2012, much of CSS is still version 3. It's furthermore not clear to me if these new improvements are really all that important to a beginner's course specifically, at least.

As an experienced programmer in other languages, but with very limited HTML and absolutely no prior CSS experience, I was able to grasp everything quickly and particularly appreciated his practical and organized approach.

Great course, I highly recommend it.

However, the code was difficult to read from the video and at times, the volume was a bit low. I look forward to taking other courses with Brad Hussey!

results.content: This course is targeted at the absolute beginner. I had hoped for more tips on a great workflow from PSD to HTML & CSS, but the PSD part played a very small role. The majority of the course was a very simple and superficial intro to HTML and CSS. I've taken other courses from Brad which were much better, but this one I can't really recommend, except for maybe the absolute beginner.

results.content:
If you want to learn:
1. How to set up a PSD document for the web.
2. The process of typing out HTML.
3. How to look at a wire frame and  write HTML from it.
4. An effective way to write and set up CSS3.
5. How to measure elements in your PSD file and applying it to CSS
6. How to position images, buttons, Headers and more. This course is for you. I'll definitely be using this again to make other web pages!

results.content:
This course was a great addition to any other of the UDEMY courses offered. In particular web dev courses. It was nice to actually create a site, from its visual PSD format to creating HTML and CSS3 for the site itself. One critique would be the speed at which the steps are outlined, however we do have the options of pausing the video. So not a huge deal. I do have another one of Brads video courses to go through. He keeps things fairy to the point and concise. 
All in all, a great starter course.

results.content: This is a course well worth taking if you want to learn how to use a PSD mockup and code it into a functional web page. There is a lot of work on HTML5 & CSS3 and some workarounds to show some cool CSS3 functionality. Great course!

results.content: This is a great course. It's full of useful information and amazing tips! I won't give it 5 full stars, cause even tho the premise of this course is to get hands on code as fast a possible to learn that way, I do think it sometimes goes too fast for someone with no experience. That would be fine if the subtitle didn't read there's absolutely no prior experience necessary (little bit misleading maybe). I have taken some web courses in the past so for me the course is working perfect. Great job!
